Title: Towards a Computational Account of Natural Sequential Behavior

This proposal seeks to develop a comprehensive computational framework to understand and model natural sequential behavior in everyday tasks. Our goal is to elucidate the intricate relationships between perception, cognition, and action in the face of uncertainty and variability. We aim to achieve this by integrating insights from psychophysics, statistical decision theory, active vision, intuitive physics, optimal control under uncertainty, navigation, and inverse reinforcement learning. Our approach will involve a combination of behavioral experiments and computational modeling, focusing on tasks such as classical psychophysical production tasks, visuomotor control, navigation, and sandwich making. By analyzing human behavior in these tasks, we expect to recover subjects' perceptual uncertainties, beliefs about tasks, subjective costs and benefits (including effort), and action variability. Building on our previous experimental work on visuomotor behavior and theoretical work on individual-by-individual and trial-by-trial modeling, this project will provide a fundamental understanding of how humans make sequential decisions under uncertainty. The proposed framework will have far-reaching implications for fields such as artificial intelligence, robotics, and cognitive science, enabling the development of more realistic and human-like sequential decision-making systems.

Title: Towards a Computational Account of Natural Sequential Behavior

This proposal aims to develop a comprehensive computational framework to understand and model human sequential behavior in everyday tasks. Our goal is to identify and characterize the perceptual, cognitive, and motor processes underlying actions involving uncertainty and variability. We will investigate how individuals make optimal decisions under uncertainty, balancing internal and external costs and benefits. 

Our interdisciplinary approach integrates methods from psychophysics, statistical decision theory, active vision, intuitive physics, optimal control under uncertainty, navigation, and inverse reinforcement learning. We will design behavioral experiments involving classical psychophysical production tasks, visuomotor control, navigation, and real-world tasks like sandwich making. 

By analyzing subjects' performance, we expect to recover their perceptual uncertainties, beliefs about tasks, subjective costs and benefits (including effort), and action variability. Building on our previous experimental work on visuomotor behavior and theoretical modeling of individual-by-individual and trial-by-trial behavior, this project will provide a fundamental understanding of human sequential behavior. The proposed framework will have significant implications for artificial intelligence, robotics, and cognitive science, enabling the development of more human-like autonomous systems and improving human-machine interaction. Ultimately, this project will advance our knowledge of human behavior and decision-making in complex, dynamic environments.
